raw_text:
McConnell details Scots wave toll
 
 At least three people from Scotland died in the tsunami disaster and a further three are on the missing list, the first minister has told MSPs.
 
 The figures came out during a statement by Jack McConnell to the Scottish Parliament on Wednesday. He formally expressed Scotland's sympathy for the victims of the Indian Ocean tidal wave which killed 150,000. Mr McConnell went on to promise that Scotland would play its part in the reconstruction effort. He said the provisional figures on the dead and lost had been provided by the police.
 
 Mr McConnell said the tragedy should persuade everyone to step up the fight against global poverty and change the world for the better. He said he was proud of the generous response of people in Scotland to the disaster appeal, which is expected soon to top £20m. The first minister also praised Scottish Water for immediately flying bottled water and five large generators to the disaster zone. The Scottish Executive has seconded 11 staff to the aid agencies.
 
 But he said Scotland was "in it for the long term" with help planned for fishing communities, for children's services, and for the aid charities. He said 2005 must be the year that Scotland showed clearly it cared for what happened to people elsewhere in the world, whether in Asia or in Africa. Mr McConnell went on to signal that the executive would play its part in the Make Poverty History campaign being mounted by a variety of aid charities, trade unions and churches in the run-up to the G8 summit in Gleneagles in July. Edinburgh architect, Dominic Stephenson, became the first Scot to be confirmed as a victim of the Asian tsunami. The 27-year-old was holidaying on the Thai island of Koh Phi Phi with Eileen Lee, 24. She is still missing.
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a summary of the text in plain text:

McConnell details Scots wave toll
* At least three people from Scotland died in Indian Ocean tsunami disaster
* Three more are listed as missing
* McConnell expresses sympathy for victims and promises reconstruction efforts
* McConnell praises Scottish response to disaster appeal, with £20m expected
llama3.2:3b: At least three Scottish people died in the Indian Ocean tsunami, and three are unaccounted for. First Minister Jack McConnell expressed Scotland's sympathy for the victims and promised to play its part in the reconstruction effort. Scotland has pledged to provide aid, including bottled water and generators, and will also support fishing communities, children's services, and aid charities.
gemma2:2b: At least three people from Scotland died in the Indian Ocean tsunami.  Jack McConnell, Scotland's first minister, expressed sympathy and promised to assist with reconstruction efforts. He also highlighted the need for global action against poverty. Donations for the relief effort have reached nearly £20 million. Scottish officials are deploying assistance to the affected regions.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Scotland's response after tsunami disaster: "in it for the long term", "play its part in reconstruction", "foster global poverty"
qwen2.5:1.5b: Scotland has lost at least three people in the tsunami disaster and is providing support through donations and assistance from organizations like Scottish Water and the Scottish Executive. The first minister promises Scotland's participation in the Make Poverty History campaign for the G8 summit. The government also plans to help fishing communities, children's services, and aid charities. The victim of the Asian tsunami was a 27-year-old Scot named Dominic Stephenson who was on a holiday with his girlfriend when tragedy struck.
qwen2.5:3b: McConnell details Scots wave toll: At least three Scottish people died in the Indian Ocean tsunami and three are missing. McConnell expressed sympathy for victims, promised Scotland's participation in reconstruction, praised generosity towards disaster appeal, and emphasized a long-term approach to aid including fishing communities and children’s services. He also supported Make Poverty History campaign leading up to G8 summit. Stephenson became first Scot confirmed as victim on Thai island of Koh Phi Phi.

Edinburgh architect, Dominic Stephenson, became the first Scot to be confirmed as a victim of the Asian tsunami. The 27-year-old was holidaying on the Thai island of Koh Phi Phi with Eileen Lee, 24. She is still missing.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Scotland's disaster response and the plans for their response. Let me read through it carefully first.

The main points seem to be: the death toll in the Tsunami in the Indian Ocean, the numbers (150k dead, more missing), the statement by Jack McConnell, his quotes on sympathy, support for global poverty, the poverty appeal reaching £20m, the provision of bottled water and generators, the 11 staff seconded to aid agencies, planning for long-term development with fishing, children's services, and charities. Then there are some highlights about Scotland showing care beyond just the immediate impact, and their involvement in a major campaign up until the G8 summit.

Alright, I should focus on the key ideas: death tolls, Scotland's role, global poverty, aid agencies involvement, support for Make Poverty History, missing people, and achievements mentioned like the architect being confirmed.

I need to make sure I include all these points without getting too detailed. Maybe start by stating how many died and more missing, then his statement, his promises, the appeal money, the aid items, and the missing person info. Also, touch on Scotland's long-term plans and their involvement in the G8 summit.

Wait, he mentioned the architect was confirmed as a survivor, that might be relevant for highlighting Scotland's care beyond immediate effects.

I should make sure each main idea is clearly stated, keeping it concise. No explanations or additional points unless necessary.
</think>

The death toll in the Tsunami in the Indian Ocean was approximately 150,000, with some missing and a further three on the missing list. Jack McConnell expressed sympathy for the victims during a statement to the Scottish Parliament. He promised Scotland's role in global reconstruction and thanked the aid agencies. The first minister praised Scotland's generous response to a disaster appeal expected to reach £20m. Scotland provided bottled water, five large generators, and seconded 11 staff members to aid agencies. Scotland is planning long-term development for fishing communities, children's services, and aid charities. A missing architect was confirmed as a survivor on the island of Koh Phi Phi.
tinyllama:1.1b: McConnell details Scot's wave toll, and MSPs express sympathy for victims, while first minister promises to play a part in global poverty fight, help fishing communities and aid charities. Scottish government official Jack McConneill also announces the provision of bottled water, five generator units, and support for children's services in aid-affected areas. The executive has planned support for fishing communities, children's services, and aid charities as well as a Make Poverty History campaign in the run-up to the G8 summit in Glennaigles. First Minister Alex Salmond also announces that Scotland is "in it for the long term" and will play its part in relief efforts.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text provided provides information about an important event that occurred in Scotland involving the tsunami disaster. Jack McConnell, First Minister of Scotland, expressed his sympathy for those affected by the disaster and promised to help them rebuild their lives. He mentioned that he would also be supporting various aid initiatives, including those related to poverty reduction, fishing communities, and child services. The text also includes information about the first victim from Scotland being named as Dominic Stephenson, an Edinburgh architect who was holidaying on a Thai island when the tsunami struck.
phi:2.7b: At least six people from Scotland died in the Indian Ocean tidal wave disaster, and three are still missing. Scottish ministers expressed sympathy for the victims and promised to help with reconstruction efforts. The tragedy should motivate a global fight against poverty and inspire compassion for people around the world. Scottish Water sent bottled water and generators to the disaster zone, while the Scottish Executive is sending staff to aid agencies. Scotland will contribute to the Make Poverty History campaign and care for the affected communities in the long term.
orca-mini:3b: McConnell details three Scottish victims of tsunami disaster and three on missing list, while promising Scotland's aid effort and support for Make Poverty History campaign.
hermes3:3b: McConnell summarizes Scots affected by tsunami in Scottish Parliament, expresses sympathy and pledges Scotland's help in reconstruction effort, long-term support for various communities.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Jack McConnell, the First Minister, informed the Scottish Parliament about the deaths in the Indian Ocean tidal wave disaster and Scotland's role in the reconstruction effort. At least three people from Scotland died, and a further three are listed as missing. He expressed sympathy for the 150,000 victims and urged everyone to fight against global poverty. The response to the disaster was praised, with £20m expected to be raised soon. Scotland has provided assistance planned for fishing communities, children's services, and aid charities in the long term. The First Minister signaled their participation in the Make Poverty History campaign during the G8 summit in July.

He expressed Scotland's sympathy for the 150,000 victims and pledged long-term support for reconstruction, including aid for fishing communities and children's services. He praised Scotland's generous response, with donations nearing £20m, and highlighted Scottish Water's immediate assistance. McConnell emphasized the need to fight global poverty and committed Scotland to the Make Poverty History campaign ahead of the G8 summit. Edinburgh architect Dominic Stephenson was the first confirmed Scottish victim, while his companion Eileen Lee remains missing.

Scotland will contribute to the reconstruction effort, and the generous response of Scots has raised funds expected to top £X for the aid appeal. Scottish Water sent bottled water and generators; aid charities will collaborate with an executive on the Make Poverty History campaign at the G8 summit in Gleneagles, leading by Edinburgh architect Dominic Stephenson, confirmed as a tsunami victim.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Three Scots, including Edinburgh architect Dominic Stephenson (27), died in the Asian tsunami, while three more are missing. First Minister Jack McConnell reported this during a parliamentary statement on Wednesday. He emphasized Scotland's commitment to reconstruction and pledged £20 million for disaster relief, expected to exceed that amount. The provisional death toll was given by the police. McConnell urged global action against poverty, citing Scotland's generous response to a disaster appeal nearing £20 million and the swift deployment of resources like bottled water and generators to the affected area. The Scottish Executive will extend its support to fishing communities, children's services, aid charities, and for the Make Poverty History campaign leading up to the G8 summit in July.
reference: At least three people from Scotland died in the tsunami disaster and a further three are on the missing list, the first minister has told MSPs.He said he was proud of the generous response of people in Scotland to the disaster appeal, which is expected soon to top £20m.But he said Scotland was "in it for the long term" with help planned for fishing communities, for children's services, and for the aid charities.Mr McConnell went on to promise that Scotland would play its part in the reconstruction effort.Mr McConnell went on to signal that the executive would play its part in the Make Poverty History campaign being mounted by a variety of aid charities, trade unions and churches in the run-up to the G8 summit in Gleneagles in July.He said 2005 must be the year that Scotland showed clearly it cared for what happened to people elsewhere in the world, whether in Asia or in Africa.
